examples.en: Can you fix this computer?
examples.ja: このパソコン、直せますか？

examples.en: I have to fix the toilet.
examples.ja: トイレを直さなければいけない。

examples.en: I will reconsider.
examples.ja: 考え直します。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. Remember how 直 can also mean <kanji>fix</kanji>? Well, this word uses that meaning, so it's <vocabulary>to fix</vocabulary>. This is when you're fixing something, as in doing the actual physical action of fixing.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You need <vocabulary>to fix</vocabulary> something <reading>now</reading> (なお)! Seriously, it's urgent! If you don't fix it now, it's going to cause big problems for everyone, so get to it right NOW!!!

examples.en: That man is a famous bestselling author.
examples.ja: あの男の人は、有名なベストセラー作家です。

examples.en: I got an autograph from the writer of this book.
examples.ja: この本の作家さんから、サインをもらいました。

examples.en: Many of the fans of this writer are women over thirty years old.
examples.ja: この作家のファンは、三十才以上の女の人が多いです。

meaning_mnemonic:
This is a strange one, but only at first glance. You <kanji>make</kanji> a <kanji>house</kanji>. You'd think this would mean something like "building a house" or "construction" or something. Instead, it means writer. Think of it this way: A <vocabulary>writer</vocabulary> <kanji>makes</kanji> (writes and creates works) in their <kanji>home</kanji>. Writers don't make their word magic in a corporate office!

作家 is generally used to refer to someone who writes professionally as an occupation, especially in the field of literature. It can also be used more broadly to refer to a creator who produces individual works of art or craft.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. Since the さく reading of 作 becomes さっ here, we've made a mnemonic for you to remember this reading:

<vocabulary>Writer</vocabulary>s love <reading>soccer</reading> (さっか). In fact, playing soccer is how they get their inspiration. Try playing some soccer, maybe you'll become a <vocabulary>creator</vocabulary> too!

examples.en: The opponent of this game seems to be strong.
examples.ja: 今回のゲームの相手は強そうだ。

examples.en: My mother's companion for chatting is her pet caterpillar.
examples.ja: 母の話し相手は、ペットの毛虫です。

examples.en: How about thinking carefully about the person you're proposing to with a flash mob?
examples.ja: フラッシュモブでプロポーズされる相手のことも、きちんと考えなよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 手 can mean a "doer"? Now, what do you think your <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>doer</kanji> might be? It’s someone who shares the same activities or tasks with you. This person could be your <vocabulary>partner</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>companion</vocabulary>, or even an <vocabulary>opponent</vocabulary> in certain situations.
reading_mnemonic:
The readings are the kun'yomi readings. For 手, that's no problem for you. For 相, that's more of an issue since you learned the on'yomi reading for it. Think of it this way: 

Your partner wouldn't be your partner without you. Your partner is: <reading>I</reading> (あい) and you. Remember that as you gaze into your partner's eyes. "I and you."

examples.en: Oh, the sun has come out.
examples.ja: あっ、太陽の光が出てきましたね。

examples.en: Do you happen to know what the sun's temperature is?
examples.ja: 太陽の温度って何度ぐらいあるか知っていますか？

examples.en: The symbol of Expo '70 was the Tower of the Sun, created by Taro Okamoto, and it's still standing in the Expo Commemoration Park in Suita, Osaka, Japan.
examples.ja: 日本万国博覧会のシンボルは、岡本太郎が作った「太陽の塔」で、それは今も日本の大阪の吹田にある万博公園にそびえ立っています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fat</kanji> <kanji>sunshine</kanji> thing up in the sky... what is it called? Oh, that's right. It's the <vocabulary>sun</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn the たい reading with the 太 kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

When the <vocabulary>sun</vocabulary> is out, you take off your <reading>tie</reading> (たい). You ever had a tie on outside when it was all sunny and hot? It's not pleasant. A tie is usually tolerable until the sun comes out — then you're super aware of how hot and uncomfortable it is. Go ahead, take off your tie.

examples.en: He is someone who prefers classical music.
examples.ja: 彼はクラシック音楽を好む人です。

examples.en: Koichi likes eating black garlic.
examples.ja: コウイチは、黒ニンニクを好んで食べます。

examples.en: My cat prefers to be alone.
examples.ja: うちのネコは一人でいることを好みます。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 好き is "like." Although 好き is kind of like a verb already, this is definitely a verb. It can be <vocabulary>to be fond of</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to like</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is a strange one, different from anything you've learned, kanji on'yomi or vocab kun'yomi. The reading is この, so think of this: 

What’s something easy <vocabulary>to be fond of</vocabulary>? <reading>子</reading>? <reading>No</reading> (この), not for you. You’re always saying “子? No!” Most people are fond of kids, at least their own, but not you. Noisy, germy, needy 子? No, no thank you!

examples.en: Since there are many different people, it is natural that a variety of opinions will be expressed.
examples.ja: 色んな人がいるので、様々な意見が出るのは当たり前です。

examples.en: I think there are various ways to interpret that remark.
examples.ja: その発言に対しては様々な受けとり方ができると思います。

examples.en: There are still various issues regarding this matter.
examples.ja: これについては、まだ様々な問題があります。

examples.en: Of course, people like different things.
examples.ja: やっぱり、好きなものは、人様々ですね。

examples.en: Even siblings raised in the same house have different personalities.
examples.ja: 同じ家で育った兄弟でも性格は様々です。

meaning_mnemonic: This one's kinda tricky. You learned 様 is a "formal name ender," but it can also mean "manner," as in the manner you do something in. So if you've got multiple manners, you've got lots of <vocabulary>various</vocabulary> ways of doing things!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the reading you learned with the kanji. The second one is ざま however, which plays right into the "various" meaning of the word. There's even various ways to read さま in this word!

examples.en: This band's vocalist is from Fukushima.
examples.ja: このバンドのボーカルは、福島の出身です。

examples.en: Fukushima is located in the Tohoku region of Japan.
examples.ja: 福島は日本の東北地方にあります。

examples.en: Fukushima has plenty of beautiful nature.
examples.ja: 福島には美しい自然がたくさんあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>luck</kanji> <kanji>island</kanji> wasn't actually too lucky. This is <vocabulary>Fukushima</vocabulary> where the nuclear meltdown happened after the 2011 earthquake. So, when you think of "luck island" this is where you should think.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. If one thing is lucky, it's probably that.

examples.en: Wow! You've mastered an amazing skill.
examples.ja: ワオ！すごい技をマスターしたね。

examples.en: What kind of technique did you use to win her over?
examples.ja: どんな技を使って彼女をゲットしたの？

examples.en: As expected, that's a pro's skill. So impressive.
examples.ja: さすが、プロの技だね。すごいわ。

meaning_mnemonic: What is a <kanji>skill</kanji>? It's something you can do, and do quite well. It is a <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary> that you can make happen with ease.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You do your <vocabulary>technique</vocabulary> on a bad guy, coming at you. You flip him over and knock him out. He <reading>was</reading> (わざ) a threat, but now he's not. You look closer at the bad guy. Turns out it's <reading>Woz</reading>, the Apple Co-founder. He was just trying to hand you an iPhone12, not grab your wrist. Whoops!

examples.en: I am working as a technical intern in Japan.
examples.ja: 私は日本で技能実習生として働いています。

examples.en: I passed the motorcycle skills test in one go.
examples.ja: バイクの技能試験は一発合格でした。

examples.en: You need to study all four skills - reading, writing, listening, and speaking - in a balanced way.
examples.ja: リーディング、ライティング、リスニング、スピーキングの四つの技能をバランスよく勉強しなくてはいけません。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>skill</kanji> and <kanji>ability</kanji> are kind of similar things. That's why this word means either or. Your skill ability is your <vocabulary>skill</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>ability</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My special skill is imitating the cries of a budgerigar.
examples.ja: 私の特技セキセイインコの鳴きマネです。

examples.en: I don't have any special skills.
examples.ja: 僕には特技は一つもありません。

examples.en: Her special skill is baking bread. She loves baking bread because she enjoys seeing everyone's happy faces.
examples.ja: 彼女の特技はパン作りです。パン作りが好きな理由は、みんなのハッピーな顔を見るのが好きだからだそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>special</kanji> <kanji>skill</kanji> is your <vocabulary>specialty</vocabulary>. So, what is your 特技?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: She has talent in art.
examples.ja: 彼女には芸術の才能があります。

examples.en: My younger sister is learning Thai art at a university of fine arts.
examples.ja: 私の妹は、芸大でタイ芸術を学んでいます。

examples.en: You need some luck to succeed in the art world.
examples.ja: 芸術の世界で成功するには運も必要だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You need <kanji>art</kanji> <kanji>technique</kanji>s to make <vocabulary>art</vocabulary>. Without art techniques, <vocabulary>the arts</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>fine art</vocabulary> simply wouldn’t exist.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am studying art at university.
examples.ja: 私は大学で美術を学んでいます。

examples.en: Would you like to join the art club?
examples.ja: よかったら、美術部に入らない？

examples.en: He reads art books to learn about different painters.
examples.ja: 彼は美術の本を読んで、様々な画家について学んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: When you create <kanji>beauty</kanji> with your <kanji>technique</kanji>s, that’s <vocabulary>fine art</vocabulary>, or simply <vocabulary>art</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Viet has decided to leave the Yakuza group and follow the teachings of Buddha.
examples.ja: ビエトはヤクザをやめて、仏の道に入ることを決意しました。

examples.en: That person may seem as serene as a Buddha, but even a Buddha can lose patience after three incidents.
examples.ja: あの人は仏のような人ですが、「仏の顔も三度まで」ですよ。

examples.en: It's often better to live by the principle of 'ignorance is bliss' and remain oblivious to unpleasant matters.
examples.ja: 私はイヤなことは知らずに、「知らぬが仏」でいる方がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You go up to <vocabulary>Buddha</vocabulary>. You want to rub his head for good luck, because that's what you hear is good to do. Right before you touch him, he backs off and says, "Whoa! I'm <reading>hot, okay</reading>?" (ほとけ). You touch him and it burns your hand clean off. 

Imagine saying "hot, okay?" in a strange accent to help you to remember.

examples.en: Buddhism originated in ancient India.
examples.ja: 仏教は古代インドから始まりました。

examples.en: I resonate with the teachings of Buddhism.
examples.ja: 私は仏教の教えに共感します。

examples.en: My friend is a Buddhist scholar and teaches Buddhist studies at a university.
examples.ja: 私の友人は仏教学者で、大学で仏教学を教えています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>buddha</kanji> <kanji>teach</kanji>ings are what you have to learn when you're studying <vocabulary>Buddhism</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that 仏 gets changed to ぶっ for this one.

examples.en: The Great Buddha is about fifteen meters tall.
examples.ja: その大仏の高さは約15メートルです。

examples.en: This Great Buddha is very famous.
examples.ja: この大仏は、とても有名な大仏です。

examples.en: No, you absolutely must see the Great Buddha.
examples.ja: いや、大仏はゼッタイ見ておいた方がいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>large</kanji> <kanji>Buddha</kanji> doesn't make sense if you don't know the context. There are giant statues of Buddha, and these are called Daibutsu, making this word translate to the <vocabulary>Great Buddha</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Giant Buddha Statue</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Whether it's true or false, if it's said by someone important, we have no choice but to believe it, right?
examples.ja: 本当かウソか分かんなくても、大切な人から言われたことなら、信じるしかないよね。

examples.en: Believe it or not, Viet turned out to be a spy.
examples.ja: 信じられないかもしれないが、実はビエトはスパイだったんだよ。

examples.en: I wonder when exactly I stopped believing in Santa Claus.
examples.ja: 自分がサンタクロースのことを信じなくなったのは、一体いつからだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>believe</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to believe</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 信 is しん no matter what! See, if you believe, good things will happen. You should be able to read this.

examples.en: I don't have a shred of confidence.
examples.ja: 自信なんて、これっぽっちもないよ。

examples.en: You should have more confidence in yourself.
examples.ja: もっと自信を持った方がいいよ！

examples.en: I'm confident that I can cherish you more than anyone else. So, please be with me.
examples.ja: 俺は誰よりも君を大切にできる自信があります。だから、俺と付き合ってください。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>believe</kanji> in your <kanji>self</kanji> you have plenty of <vocabulary>confidence</vocabulary> (or <vocabulary>self confidence</vocabulary>). This is a good thing to have!
reading_mnemonic: How much 自信 do you have that you know how to read this word already? I bet you have some, at least! This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, there's a traffic light over there.
examples.ja: あ、あそこに信号がある。

examples.en: Let's make sure to stop at the red light.
examples.ja: 赤信号ではちゃんと止まりましょう。

examples.en: In Japan, they say "blue light" instead of "green light".
examples.ja: 日本では緑信号とは言わずに青信号って言うんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>believe</kanji> in the <kanji>number</kanji>s, there will be no traffic because the <vocabulary>traffic light</vocabulary> will be functioning properly. Traffic lights are based all off of traffic data and numbers. You just have to believe and hope it all works out in terms of these traffic lights.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My mother is a deeply religious person.
examples.ja: 私の母は信心深い人です。

examples.en: Alright, everyone? By cherishing faith, our hearts become stronger.
examples.ja: いいですか、皆さん。信心を大切にすることで、心が強くなるんです。

examples.en: I want to live by helping others, whether they have faith in God or not.
examples.ja: 私は神への信心がある人ともない人とも、みんなと助け合って生きていきたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: What you <kanji>believe</kanji> in your <kanji>heart</kanji>, and not in your head, is your <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary>. This is something that doesn't follow logic, it's all heart belief, it's all <vocabulary>faith</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that しん changes to じん.

examples.en: His words carry credibility.
examples.ja: 彼の言葉には信用があります。

examples.en: She is trusted by everyone in the company.
examples.ja: 彼女は社内のみんなから信用されています。

examples.en: I lost trust because I lied twice.
examples.ja: 二回もウソをついたせいで、信用を失ってしまったんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When someone <kanji>believes</kanji> in your <kanji>task</kanji>, it means they have a lot of <vocabulary>trust</vocabulary> in what you do. You've clearly gained a great deal of <vocabulary>credibility</vocabulary> through your previous tasks.

信用 refers to the trust one party places in another's integrity and ability to fulfill obligations. It's often used to describe reliability in actions, faithfulness in relationships, or creditworthiness in financial transactions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: To be honest, I felt a bit of distrust in the words of that shop assistant.
examples.ja: 正直、その店員の言葉には、少し不信感を感じました。

examples.en: As a result of that incident, I became distrustful of people.
examples.ja: 私はそのことがきっかけで、人間不信になってしまいました。

examples.en: Every time I hear from different people, my distrust towards doctors in this country only grows.
examples.ja: 色々な方から話を聞くたびに、この国の医者への不信はつのるばかりです。

meaning_mnemonic: When you can't (<kanji>not</kanji>) <kanji>believe</kanji> in someone, it's because you <vocabulary>distrust</vocabulary> them. Maybe someone <vocabulary>discredit</vocabulary>ed them and now you <vocabulary>mistrust</vocabulary> everything they say.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: No, I haven't replied yet.
examples.ja: いや、まだ返信してない。

examples.en: It's taking forever to get a reply.
examples.ja: いつまでたっても返信が来ないんだよね。

examples.en: I thought I replied, but it turns out it didn't send.
examples.ja: 返信したつもりだったんだけど、送信できてなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: You gotta <kanji>believe</kanji> it will <kanji>return</kanji>. What are you believing in returning? The <vocabulary>reply</vocabulary>. You made a request for something (come up with something you want really bad but have to ask for). Now you wait for the reply.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Let's have the courage to try new things.
examples.ja: 勇気を持って新しいことにチャレンジしてみましょう。

examples.en: It's not good to say that to someone who gathered the courage to speak up.
examples.ja: 勇気を出して声を上げた人に、そんなこと言うのは良くないよ。

examples.en: WaniKani users were encouraged by Koichi's speech.
examples.ja: ワニカニユーザーは、コウイチのスピーチに勇気づけられました。

meaning_mnemonic: That <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>courage</kanji> is <vocabulary>courage</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I work at the ward office of Chuo-ku.
examples.ja: 私は、中央区の区役所で働いています。

examples.en: Can you name all twenty three wards of Tokyo?
examples.ja: 東京23区、全部言えますか？

examples.en: My house is located in Setagaya Ward. The Setagaya Ward is known as a comfortable living area.
examples.ja: 私の家は世田谷区にあります。世田谷区は住みやすいエリアとして知られています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji!

examples.en: This district is family oriented and easy to live in.
examples.ja: この地区はファミリー向けで住みやすいです。

examples.en: He is the player who was chosen as the representative of the district in last year's tournament.
examples.ja: 彼は、去年の大会で地区の代表に選ばれた選手です。

examples.en: The residents of that district are all cooperative when it comes to district events.
examples.ja: その地区の住民は、みんな地区の行事に協力的です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>earth</kanji> <kanji>district</kanji> isn't our solar system or something like that. We're talking about a specific portion of earth, and naming it as a district. So, what is this patch of earth? It's a <vocabulary>district</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>area</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>zone</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It was just pure luck, that's all.
examples.ja: 単にラッキーだっただけですよ。

examples.en: I just got dumped, plain and simple.
examples.ja: 単にフラれただけですよ。

examples.en: He not only excels in academics but he also has talent in sports and music.
examples.ja: 彼は単に勉強ができるだけでなく、スポーツや音楽にも才能があります。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're moving towards (に) <kanji>simple</kanji>, you're saying <vocabulary>simply</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>merely</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>only</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: WaniKani is good for learning Japanese vocabulary.
examples.ja: 日本語の単語学習には、ワニカニがいいですよ。

examples.en: Maybe I've heard that word for the first time. What does it mean?
examples.ja: その単語、初めて聞いたかも。どういう意味？

examples.en: I compiled a list of "confusing English words" that often appear on tests.
examples.ja: テストにもよく出てくる「まぎらわしい英単語」をまとめました。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>simple</kanji> bits of <kanji>language</kanji> are the individual <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>s. If you think about it, this is true. First of all, there are a ton of them. Second, they're tiny. They're just little bits of language and the "word" for these little bits is <vocabulary>word</vocabulary>.

So what’s the difference between this and 言葉? Well, 言葉 can cover any meaningful set of words – anything from words, sentences and paragraphs, to whole texts and even languages. 単語, on the other hand, is a subset of 言葉 that specifically refers to single, distinct words.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is my boss.
examples.ja: 彼は私の上司です。

examples.en: I have a meeting with my boss today.

変化 generally refers to a natural or spontaneous change, like changes from growth or aging, alterations in weather conditions, or shifts in one's emotions.

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>big</kanji> <kanji>change</kanji> is a really <vocabulary>serious</vocabulary> thing. And people don't like change, either, making it a <vocabulary>terrible</vocabulary> event. 

Also, in more recent history this has come to mean <vocabulary>very</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What year did Shanghai Incident occur?

examples.en: I like a band called Tokyo Jihen.
examples.ja: 私は東京事変というバンドが好きです。

examples.en: This incident is known as the Mukden Incident in China.
examples.ja: この事変は、中国では九一八事変として知られています。

meaning_mnemonic:
An <kanji>occurrence</kanji> that causes <kanji>change</kanji> somehow can also be called an <vocabulary>incident</vocabulary>. 

事変 is a formal word for big, unexpected incidents that are disruptive and chaotic. This can involve natural disasters, sudden riots, or other large-scale disturbances that need military intervention. It can also refer to unannounced warfare.

You'll most likely see this word used in names for historical events, like the Manshuu Jihen (満州事変), or the Manchurian Incident. The 変 kanji suggests "change," so you know 事変 is only used for historical incidents big enough to make things change!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Think about your <vocabulary>husband</vocabulary> even if you don't have one. What's his name? It's <reading>Otto</reading> (おっと), and he's always leaving you at home because he's working at the <reading>auto</reading> (おっと) shop.

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>return home</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to return home</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to return</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to go home</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. You can return home happily, knowing how to read this word! 

This word has a pair verb though, so you'll want to remember the る ending. Just imagine how <reading>ru</reading>de (る) it is when someone goes home without saying goodbye. The nerve!

reading_mnemonic: Oof. The reading for this word makes no sense. You'll have to forget everything you've learned about the readings of the kanji and just go straight up mnemonic for the word on its own. Okay. Think about what you did yesterday, all day. You played <reading>keno</reading> (きのう), gambling away your grandmother's money. Yesterday was the worst day ever because you lost everything playing Keno. Today is different, not like yesterday, right?

meaning_mnemonic:
This word is made of <kanji>now</kanji> and <kanji>night</kanji> with the hiragana は at the end. The は here is pronounced as わ (the old pronunciation). When you say "now night!" you're really saying <vocabulary>good evening</vocabulary>.

Just keep in mind that writing 今晩は is pretty old school. These days it's almost always written as こんばんは.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just be aware that the は at the end is actually the particle は so it's pronounced like わ.

meaning_mnemonic:

有毒 is a relatively formal word generally used to describe toxic materials or substances. It can also be used for formal classifications like 有毒植物 (<vocabulary>poisonous</vocabulary> plants) or 有毒動物 (poisonous and venomous animals).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
