examples.ja: この子猫はまだおねしょをします。

examples.en: I uploaded a video to Youtube of a kitty walking clockwise, round and round.
examples.ja: 子猫が時計回りにクルクル歩き回っている動画をYoutubeにアップロードしました。

examples.en: I found and took home three cute kittens today.
examples.ja: 今日、かわいい子猫を三匹拾いました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>child</kanji> <kanji>cat</kanji> is an adorable <vocabulary>kitten</vocabulary>. D'awww!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the vocab word 子 (こ) and the reading for cat (ねこ).

examples.en: Today's fashion is very autumnal.
examples.ja: 今日は秋っぽいファッションだね。

examples.en: Autumn nights have beautiful stars.
examples.ja: 秋の夜は星がきれいです。

examples.en: Even though it was autumn and the trees were changing colors, I still did not receive a reply from you.
examples.ja: 秋になり木々が色づいても、君からの返事はまだ来なかった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, <reading>あき</reading>.

examples.en: "What century is it right now?" "It's the 21st century."
examples.ja: 「今って何世紀だっけ？」「二十一世紀だよ。」

examples.en: Koichi wants to live at least a century.
examples.ja: コウイチは少なくとも一世紀は生きたいと思っている。

examples.en: Advances in artificial intelligence and robotics are being closely watched in this century.
examples.ja: 今世紀にはAIやロボットの進歩が注目されています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>account</kanji> of a <kanji>generation</kanji>... this covers a whole generation, and considering how long Japanese people live, this account totals a whole <vocabulary>century</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Did you know that in 64 A.D. there was a huge fire in Rome?
examples.ja: 紀元後64年にローマで大火事が発生したのを知っていますか？

examples.en: Papyrus was in use until about the 10th century A.D.
examples.ja: パピルスは紀元後10世紀ぐらいまで使われていた。

examples.en: Oh, your Japanese so much better than last time we met, isn't it? It's like two different eras.
examples.ja: え、こないだ会った時より日本語めっちゃ上手になってない？紀元前と紀元後くらいちがうじゃん。

meaning_mnemonic:
What does the <kanji>narrative</kanji> <kanji>origin</kanji> have coming <kanji>after</kanji> it? Well, the way we've counted years for the past couple of millenia has a specific narrative at its origin, and everything that comes after it is the <vocabulary>Common Era</vocabulary>, aka <vocabulary>AD</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>anno Domini</vocabulary>.

Just in case you don't know what narrative we're talking about: it's the narrative of Jesus's birth, which is the year that we say the Common Era started.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am studying English.
examples.ja: 私は英語を勉強しています。

examples.en: She speaks English fluently.
examples.ja: 彼女は英語がペラペラです。

examples.en: Your English pronunciation is very good.
examples.ja: あなたの英語の発音はとても良いですね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>language</kanji> is the language you're reading right here and now. This is the <vocabulary>English language</vocabulary>. It is <vocabulary>English</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My older brother is good at English conversations, but bad at calculations.
examples.ja: 私の兄は、英会話は上手だけど、計算は苦手なんです。

examples.en: Oh no, I can’t believe I failed another English conversation test. I’m so shocked.
examples.ja: まさか。また英会話のテストに落ちちゃったよ。ショックすぎる。

examples.en: I teach business English at an English conversation school.
examples.ja: 私は英会話教室でビジネス英語を教えています。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji>ing and <kanji>talk</kanji>ing with each other. This is <vocabulary>English Conversation</vocabulary>. This is used a lot when talking about "speaking in English" for studying English and whatnot.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Her English writing is easy to understand and read.
examples.ja: 彼女の英文は分かりやすくて読みやすいです。

examples.en: I have to finish up my report in English by the end of the month.
examples.ja: 月末までに英文でレポートを仕上げなくてはいけません。

examples.en: My child won an award in an English essay contest.
examples.ja: うちの子は、英文の作文コンテストで賞を受賞しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>England</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is <vocabulary>English Writing</vocabulary> (or if you want to be fancy, <vocabulary>English Composition</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is from England.
examples.ja: 彼は英国出身です。

examples.en: I am studying English Literature at a university in the UK.
examples.ja: 私は英国の大学で英文学を学んでいます。

examples.en: It is raining again today in the UK.
examples.ja: 英国は今日も雨です。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>England</kanji> <kanji>country</kanji> is where England is. This word can refer to <vocabulary>Britain</vocabulary>, the <vocabulary>United Kingdom</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>England</vocabulary>!

Note that イギリス is more common for "England" - but, since this is a kanji learning website you should learn this word.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is English-to-Japanese, right?
examples.ja: これ、英和だっけ？

examples.en: Oh no, I thought it was English-to-Japanese, but it turned out to be Japanese-to-English!
examples.ja: ゲ、英和だと思って買ったら、和英だった！

examples.en: She goes to an English-Japanese Women's Academy.
examples.ja: 彼女は英和女学院に通っています。

meaning_mnemonic: This is seen on things like dictionaries. When you have an <kanji>English</kanji> and <kanji>Japanese</kanji> (style) dictionary, for example. You'll see it the other way around too, but this particular one is <vocabulary>English Japanese</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My company president wears a Rolex watch.
examples.ja: うちの社長の時計はロレックスです。

examples.en: We're gonna meet at the clock tower at 3 p.m., okay?
examples.ja: 時計台の下で、三時に待ち合わせね！

examples.en: Isn't the sound of this clock loud? It's distracting me from concentrating.
examples.ja: この時計の音、うるさくない？気になって集中できない。

meaning_mnemonic: A thing that gives you <kanji>time</kanji> <kanji>measurement</kanji>s is a <vocabulary>watch</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>clock</vocabulary>. Most people have these in their phones instead of on their wrists now.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is pretty weird. 計 is all nice and normal, but 時 is と for some reason. It probably is coming from the vocab word 時 (とき), is my guess. But even if it is, it's shortened, making it a step more complicated. Maybe it's just better to imagine that your <vocabulary>watch</vocabulary> is a walky <reading>talky</reading> (とけい) and run with that?

examples.en: That will be a total of three thousand yen.
examples.ja: 合計で三千円になります。

examples.en: The total of numbers from one to ten is fifty-five.
examples.ja: 1から10までの数字の合計は55です。

examples.en: When we totaled the number of people who came to today's event, it was more than we expected.
examples.ja: 今日のイベントに来た人の人数を合計すると、予想以上の人数でした。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>join</kanji> all your <kanji>measure</kanji>ments together you have yourself a <vocabulary>total</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: We are planning to go to the beach during summer vacation.
examples.ja: 夏休みに海に行こうと計画しています。

examples.en: I like to plan but I don't like to carry out what I've planned.
examples.ja: 計画を立てるのは大好きなんですけど、計画したことを実行するのはきらいなんです。

examples.en: This plan carries risks, but if successful, the rewards are significant.
examples.ja: この計画にはリスクがありますが、成功すれば大きいです。

meaning_mnemonic: You need <kanji>measurement</kanji>s and <kanji>image</kanji>s to make a <vocabulary>plan</vocabulary>. You can't follow a plan without measurements and images to refer to, right? Any good plan has measurements and drawings.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading for 画 is the secondary reading though (かく), so take note of that.

examples.en: He is quick at calculations.
examples.ja: 彼は計算が速いです。

examples.en: Is this calculation correct?
examples.ja: この計算、合ってる？

examples.en: That woman is famous for being calculating.
examples.ja: あの女は計算高いことで有名です。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>measure</kanji> and then <kanji>calculate</kanji> something, you are making a <vocabulary>calculation</vocabulary>. For example, you measure the length of a frog, then you calculate how many frogs you'd need to reach the moon. What is that? A calculation, of course.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: My father is a former soldier.
examples.ja: うちの父は元軍人です。

examples.en: Look, there are a lot of servicemen over there. I wonder what's going on?
examples.ja: 見て、あそこに軍人さんがたくさんいる。どうしたんだろう？

examples.en: In that war, over 500,000 servicemen lost their lives.
examples.ja: その戦争では、50万人以上の軍人が命を落としました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>army</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is someone in the army. What are those people called? They're <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I heard that my grandfather was a sailor in the Navy.
examples.ja: 僕のおじいちゃんは、海軍の軍人だったそうです。

examples.en: This is something used by the British Navy during World War II.
examples.ja: これは、第二次世界大戦の時に、イギリスの海軍が使っていたものです。

examples.en: The Japanese Navy used to eat curry once a week. This curry is now sold as "Navy Curry" even in retort pouches.
examples.ja: 日本の海軍は、週に一度カレーを食べていました。このカレーは、今では「海軍カレー」としてレトルトでも売られています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>sea</kanji> <kanji>army</kanji> are the branch of the military that has boats and does ocean/sea things. What's that? The <vocabulary>navy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: How about we go grab a meal sometime?
examples.ja: 今度、飯でも行かない？

examples.en: Hey, still no food? I'm starving.
examples.ja: ねー、飯まだ？ハラペコなんだけど。

examples.en: This employee prefers working to eating three meals a day.
examples.ja: この社員は三度の飯より仕事をするのが好きです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It also refers to <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>, because you gotta eat cooked rice with every meal, so it's basically synonymous with "meal" itself.

This word has a slightly gruff feel to it so it's used mostly in informal situations.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You're eating a <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>... MMmm, delicious! What are you eating? Well, it's a <reading>Mesh</reading> (めし) net. Taste the mesh net. It tastes terrible. This is a bad meal. Feel it in your mouth. It's weird and meshy.

examples.en: I always eat out for lunch.
examples.ja: お昼はいつも外でご飯を食べます

examples.en: Damn it! I just spilled my rice.
examples.ja: しまった！ご飯こぼしちゃった。

examples.en: I wonder what to make for dinner tonight.
examples.ja: 今日の夜ご飯は何を作ろうかな。

meaning_mnemonic: The ご just makes this word more polite and fancy — two important qualities when it comes to food. This has the same meaning as the kanji (<kanji>meal</kanji>), making it <vocabulary>meal</vocabulary>, but it can also just mean <vocabulary>cooked rice</vocabulary>. So, "Come eat your ご飯" can mean either "come eat your rice" or "come eat your meal" — or both, since most Japanese meals come with rice anyway.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now how about you "<reading>han</reading>d" me another bowl of rice?

examples.en: He is clumsy and struggles to learn new things.
examples.ja: 彼は不器用で、新しいことを学ぶのが苦手です。

examples.en: Despite her clumsiness, she never gave up.
examples.ja: 不器用ながらも、彼女は決してあきらめませんでした。

examples.en: With clumsy words, he expressed his gratitude to his parents.
examples.ja: 彼は不器用な言葉で、親に感謝の気持ちを伝えました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how 器用 means "dextrous" and "skillful"? Well, this is when you're <kanji>not</kanji> those things. When you're not dextrous, you're <vocabulary>clumsy</vocabulary> and when you're not skillful you're <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just keep in mind that the reading of 不 changes from ふ to ぶ. If you're clumsy you'll get a lot of <reading>boo</reading>-boos (ぶ), get it?

examples.en: Please! Help me!
examples.ja: お願い！手伝って！

examples.en: I have a favor to ask you, would you hear me out?
examples.ja: ちょっとお願いがあるんだけど、聞いてもらえる？

examples.en: Please, let's stop talking about that.
examples.ja: お願いだから、その話はもうやめて。

meaning_mnemonic: The noun form of <kanji>request</kanji> (don't be tricked by the い on the end, it's not an adjective). So, request goes to <vocabulary>a request</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same like お願いします. Hopefully you're able to read that by now so you're able to read this too.

examples.en: It looks like this restaurant has an all-you-can-drink option.
examples.ja: このレストランは飲み放題があるみたいだよ。

examples.en: The all-you-can-drink plans start at 2000 yen.
examples.ja: 飲み放題プランは2000円からです。

examples.en: We booked a course that includes all-you-can-drink.
examples.ja: 飲み放題付きのコースを予約しました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Drink</kanji>ing <kanji>as much as you want</kanji> is nice and all, but don't get sick. When you see this word, you know you're at an <vocabulary>all you can drink</vocabulary> place. Tip: Usually there's a time limit, so drink up!
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the word 放題 (ほうだい) and 飲む (のむ). So long as you know those vocab words, you'll be able to read this one as well.

examples.en: This hotel breakfast is all-you-can-eat.
examples.ja: このホテルの朝食は食べ放題です。

examples.en: Let's go to an all-you-can-eat pizza place.
examples.ja: 食べ放題のピザ屋に行こう。

examples.en: In Japan, there are cafes that offer all-you-can-eat cake.
examples.ja: 日本にはケーキ食べ放題のカフェがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>eat</kanji> <kanji>as much as you want</kanji>, you are getting an <vocabulary>all you can eat</vocabulary> deal.
reading_mnemonic: The reading consists of the readings of 食べる and 放題. If you know those you should be able to read this too.

examples.en: That man is a murderer.
examples.ja: その男は人殺しです。

examples.en: No one wants to send their own child to the battlefield to become a killer.
examples.ja: 自分の子を戦場に送り出して、人殺しをさせたい人なんていませんよ。

examples.en: People who speak ill of others on social media should consider that they might be committing murder in a sense.
examples.ja: SNSで悪口を言ってる人は全員、自分が人殺しをしているかもしれないってことを考えた方がいいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>kill</kanji> a <kanji>person</kanji> that's <vocabulary>murder</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, if you know 人's reading as a vocab word and 殺す's reading, you should be able to read this word. Just note that ころし goes to ごろし due to rendaku.

examples.en: This murderer is a notorious serial killer.
examples.ja: この殺人者は、有名なシリアルキラーです。

examples.en: Believe me, my son was just framed as a murderer by someone.
examples.ja: 信じてください。息子は誰かに殺人者に仕立て上げられただけなんです。

examples.en: Have you ever considered the pain of someone whose family member was a murderer?
examples.ja: あなたは家族が殺人者だった人の苦しみについて、考えたことはありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 殺人 (murder) from level 13. So, <kanji>someone</kanji> who does <kanji>murder</kanji> is what? A <vocabulary>murderer</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The ring fit perfectly on her finger.
examples.ja: その指輪は彼女の指にぴったり合っていました。

examples.en: I can't get this ring off of my finger.
examples.ja: 指輪が指から外れなくなってしまいました。

examples.en: "When I get a bonus, I’ll buy you a diamond ring." "You always say that, but words are just words."
examples.ja: 「ボーナスが出たら、ダイヤモンドの指輪を買ってやるよ。」「あなたはいつも口先ばかりでしょ。」

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>finger</kanji> <kanji>ring</kanji> is the kind of <vocabulary>ring</vocabulary> you'd put on your finger. That's just simply a "ring" though, so you'll have to know what "ring" this is via context.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the individual vocab readings, 指 and 輪. In English we don't distinguish some other ring from a "finger ring" but in Japanese, you can think of this as two separate words coming together to form one word, which is why it uses the kun'yomi vocab readings like this. So, if you know the individual words, you should be able to figure out this word is read as <reading>ゆびわ</reading>.

examples.en: This elastic band is very durable.
examples.ja: この輪ゴムはとても丈夫です。

examples.en: She used a rubber band instead of a hair tie.
examples.ja: 彼女はヘアゴムの代わりに輪ゴムを使いました。

examples.en: If it's rubber bands you're looking for, there should be several on that desk.
examples.ja: 輪ゴムなら、あのデスクの上に何本かあるはずですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>ring</kanji> of gum (ゴム) (which is what Japanese people call rubber quite often) is a ring of rubber. What is a ring of rubber that people use often? It's a <vocabulary>rubber band</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 輪 is the kun'yomi vocab reading, which is わ, making this word <reading>わ</reading>ゴム.

examples.en: Oh, do you have to memorize all of this?
examples.ja: え、これ全部暗記するの？

examples.en: By using WaniKani, you can easily memorize Japanese vocabulary.
examples.ja: ワニカニを使えば、日本語の単語を楽に暗記することができます。

examples.en: I have to memorize my lines from the script by tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日までに、台本のセリフを暗記しなければいけないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Hopefully you've seen 暗記 before now. It means "memorization." So, turn that into a verb and you have <vocabulary>to memorize</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 暗記. It also is the reading you learned with the kanji too.

examples.en: Where are you going to practice?
examples.ja: どこで練習するの？

examples.en: I don't want to regret it later thinking "I should have practiced more," so I'm practicing a lot now.
examples.ja: 後から「もっとたくさん練習しておけば良かった」と思いたくないんで、今たくさん練習しています。

examples.en: I practiced pronouncing the word "meat" for six hours yesterday.
examples.ja: 昨日、肉って言葉の発音を六時間も練習したんだぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: You've hopefully seen 練習, which means "practice." So, if you make it into a verb, you have <vocabulary>to practice</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji as well as from the vocab word 練習. You should be able to read this!

examples.en: An unusual incident happened that year.
examples.ja: その年に、変事が起きたんです。

examples.en: I think we should simulate what to do in case something strange happens.
examples.ja: 変事が発生した場合のシミュレーションをしておくべきだと思います。

examples.en: All WaniKani users were worried that some unusual incident had befallen Tofugu.
examples.ja: トーフグに何か変事が起きたんじゃないかと、全ワニカニユーザーが心配していたんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
You know 変 means "change," but it can also mean "strange." So a <kanji>strange</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is an incident that is unlikely. In other words, an <vocabulary>unexpected incident</vocabulary> or an <vocabulary>unusual incident</vocabulary>.

変事 is a formal word used to describe sudden and unusual occurrences that disrupt normal conditions, such as natural disasters, emergencies, or crises. You won't see this word often, but may still come across it in formal writing.

With 変事, think of how the 変 comes first to emphasize the strangeness of the incident.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Sorry, I'm currently syncing data, so please wait a moment.
examples.ja: ごめん、今データ同期中だからちょっと待って。

examples.en: Dropbox always freezes during syncing for some reason. I wonder why.
examples.ja: Dropbox、いつも同期中にフリーズしちゃうんだよね。何でだろう。

examples.en: Yesterday, Google Drive was syncing all morning, so I couldn't get any work done.
examples.ja: 昨日はGoogleドライブがずっと同期中で午前中仕事にならなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: You're making things in two different places be exactly the <kanji>same</kanji> for <kanji>a period of time</kanji>. You're in the <kanji>middle</kanji> of a process called <vocabulary>syncing</vocabulary>. You can see 同期中 a lot in computery contexts, or if you change your device language to Japanese. (Not that I recommend that...)
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There is an old temple in the town.
examples.ja: その町には古い寺があります。

examples.en: I'm planning to draw a fortune slip at the temple during New Year's.
examples.ja: お正月にお寺でおみくじを引いてみるつもりです。

examples.en: There was a cherry blossom tree standing at the entrance of the temple.
examples.ja: その寺の入り口には、サクラの木が一本立っていました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji too! What good fortune — you must have been praying to Benzaiten at the local お寺.

examples.en: Costs will also increase in proportion.
examples.ja: それに比例して、コストも上がります。

examples.en: Do you see how this is proportional to the value of y?
examples.ja: これがyの大きさに比例するのは分かりますか？

examples.en: I think the enjoyment I get from work is proportional to how hard it is.
examples.ja: ボクは、仕事の大変さと楽しさは比例すると思うんだ。

examples.en: Foreign language proficiency doesn't necessarily improve in proportion to the amount of time spent studying.
examples.ja: 外国語能力は、学習時間に比例して高くなるというワケではない。

meaning_mnemonic:
You <kanji>compare</kanji> <kanji>example</kanji>s, trying to figure out in which way they're <vocabulary>being proportional</vocabulary>. You know these examples you're comparing are in <vocabulary>proportion</vocabulary> to one another, you just need to figure out how. 

Use 比例 when talking about how one thing changes in proportion to another. Like the price of a good in proportion to its supply and demand, for instance. Check out our common word combinations and context sentences for some examples!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: If Maria were here, this math problem would be solved in five seconds flat. They're a piece of cake for her.
examples.ja: もしここにマリアがいたら、こんな数学の問題五秒で解けちゃうよ。マリアにとってはちょちょいのちょいだね。

examples.en: That riddle is so hard! It took an hour to finally be solved.
examples.ja: そのナゾナゾ、めっちゃむずかしいよ！一時間かかってやっと解けた。

examples.en: I hope the mystery will be solved soon.
examples.ja: 早くナゾが解けるといいんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>solve</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to be solved</vocabulary>. In a similar vein, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be cleared</vocabulary>, like with misunderstandings or tension in a room.

解ける is an intransitive verb, so it doesn't take a direct object. In other words, you use it to say something is solved or gets solved. You can remember this because you don't <reading>care</reading> (ける) enough to solve things yourself, you just let things get solved on their own.
reading_mnemonic: You already learned how to read 解く, and this uses the same reading for the kanji. Lucky you!

examples.en: This dish is very delicious.
examples.ja: この料理はとても美味しいです。

examples.en: The croissants from that bakery were delicious.
examples.ja: そのベーカリーのクロワッサンは、とても美味しかったです。

examples.en: Honestly, working with this team at this company is quite fortunate.
examples.ja: 正直、この会社のこのチームで働けるのはかなり美味しいです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Something with a <kanji>beauty</kanji> <kanji>taste</kanji> is something that is really <vocabulary>tasty</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. Mmmm, yum!

While 美味しい mostly describes tasty food, you may also occasionally see it being used for a sweet deal or situation that benefits you.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this makes no sense at all. You'll have to learn it straight up, that is, unless you know the word おいしい already, which many people do as it's used in every other sentence in every Japanese variety show. If you don't know this word already, just think of yourself eating something <vocabulary>delicious</vocabulary>. It's so delicious it makes you mad, I have no idea why. You yell at the chef: "<reading>OI</reading> (おい). OI! WHY IS THIS SO DELICIOUS????"

examples.en: Understood.
examples.ja: 了解しました。

examples.en: Got it! I'll head over there right now.
examples.ja: 了解！今すぐそっちに向かうよ。

examples.en: Understood. Let's take time to discuss it tomorrow.
examples.ja: 了解です。明日ゆっくり話し合いましょう。

examples.en: At our office, there's a tacit understanding that we should not eat Mami's bacon without her permission.
examples.ja: うちのオフィスには、マミのベーコンを勝手に食べてはいけないという暗黙の了解がある。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you've <kanji>finish</kanji>ed <kanji>solv</kanji>ing something, you've come to a point of <vocabulary>understanding</vocabulary>. 

了解 is often used to show your understanding of information or instructions that have been communicated to you, similar to "<vocabulary>Got it</vocabulary>" or "<vocabulary>Understood</vocabulary>." It can also be used to show agreement, approval, or consent, since those things naturally depend on mutual understanding too.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Oh, it's okay. I'll pay for it.
examples.ja: あ、いいよ。オレが払うよ。

examples.en: I’ll pay on your behalf for now.
examples.ja: ここは私が代わりに払っておきます！

examples.en: The queen quickly dusted off her chair and sat down in it.
examples.ja: 女王は、サッとホコリを払って、イスに座った。

examples.en: Before sending an email, pay attention to grammar and spelling mistakes.
examples.ja: メールを送る前に、文法やスペルミスに注意を払いましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>pay</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to pay</vocabulary>.

This word also means <vocabulary>to brush off</vocabulary>, like when you brush dirt or dust off of something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: When you become an adult, it's difficult to change your way of thinking.
examples.ja: 大人になると、考え方を変えることはむずかしいです。

examples.en: She changed the interior of the room to change her mood.
examples.ja: 彼女は部屋のインテリアを変えて、気分を変えました。

examples.en: Oh, please do not change the shape of Tofugu's lips. They were inspired by Koichi's favorite food, cod roe.
examples.ja: あっ、トーフグのくちびるの形は変えないでください。それはコウイチの好物のタラコをモチーフにしているんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
The kanji is <kanji>change</kanji>, and this verb is <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary>. If you change one thing for another thing, you are going <vocabulary>to change</vocabulary> it, after all. This word refers to changing one thing for a similar thing.

変える and 代える sound the same and are sometimes used in similar contexts, but are different in nuance. 変える refers to the act of making something different, and involves altering the nature or state of something. For example, changing the layout of a room or changing one's perspective on an issue. 代える means to substitute or exchange one thing for another that is expected to fulfill the same role, use or purpose, such as replacing a worker with a substitute.
reading_mnemonic:
This word uses the kun'yomi, which you didn't learn with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you out.

You want <vocabulary>to change something</vocabulary> about your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) but you don't quite know what yet. Maybe your car should have a really cool feature, like a hot tub or a giant screen. Try to think of the silliest ways you could change your car.

examples.en: The man shouted at the three rats.
examples.ja: 男は、三匹のネズミに向かって大声を上げた。

examples.en: How many pet snakes does the queen have?
examples.ja: 一体、女王様のペットのヘビは何匹いるんだ？

examples.en: We keep the bigger dog in the garage and the other one in our house.
examples.ja: 大きい方の犬はガレージにいて、もう一匹は室内にいるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: There were four dragons on the Tokyo Tower.
examples.ja: 東京タワーの上に、四匹のドラゴンが止まっていた。

examples.en: There are four black cats at Matilda's house.
examples.ja: マチルダさんの家には、黒猫が四匹もいる。

examples.en: I’d like four of each of these crickets here.
examples.ja: ここにいるコオロギ、四匹ずつください。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Four</kanji> <kanji>small animal</kanji>s is <vocabulary>four small animals</vocabulary>. Use this to count four dogs, or cats, or whatever else.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My son isn't very healthy and he gets sick often.
examples.ja: 息子はあまり体が丈夫ではなく、よく病気になります。

examples.en: This chair is very sturdy, so it's perfect even for sumo wrestlers.
examples.ja: このイスはとても丈夫なので、力士にもピッタリです。

examples.en: Please make sure to practice proper dental care every day! Strong teeth are a lifelong treasure.
examples.ja: 毎日しっかりデンタルケアをしてくださいね！丈夫な歯は一生の宝物ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: With the <kanji>height</kanji> of my <kanji>husband</kanji>, he's very <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>. Try to push him over. Impossible. He's so tall and <vocabulary>sturdy</vocabulary> due to his height.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Watch out for the rendaku.

examples.en: I bought a pair of three-quarter-length pants at UNIQLO.
examples.ja: ユニクロで、七分丈のパンツを買いました。

examples.en: Isn't the length of those pants a bit short?
examples.ja: そのズボン、ちょっと丈が短いんじゃない？

examples.en: The trend among high school girls this year is to wear longer skirts.
examples.ja: 今年は、女子高生の間でスカートの丈を長くするのが流行っています。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This word is usually used for clothing <vocabulary>height</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>length</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. Remember the word 竹? It has the same reading as this. Just think of everyone measuring the heights of things with <reading>bamboo</reading> (たけ) poles with markers on them. Okay, this one is 5 bamboo poles high!

examples.en: You should make the foundation as firm as possible.
examples.ja: 土台はできるだけ頑丈にしておいた方がいいですよ。

examples.en: This car is solidly built.
examples.ja: この車はとても頑丈にできています。

examples.en: I had a really solid pair of glasses made by my optician.
examples.ja: メガネ屋さんで、とても頑丈なメガネを作ってもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>stubborn</kanji> <kanji>height</kanji> is a shorter, stockier height. It makes a person especially <vocabulary>solid</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>firm</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>stout</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

meanings: To Show Someone What One Can Do

examples.en: It's a good idea to develop the habit of reviewing tests afterward.
examples.ja: テストを最後に見返すクセをつけた方がいいですよ。

examples.en: When I gave the kitten some sardines, she looked back at me with a face that was like, "Is this really for me?!" and it was super cute.
examples.ja: 子猫にイワシをあげたら、「本当にいいの？」って感じの顔でマジマジと見返してきたのがマジかわいかった。

examples.en: I will be the Tofugu president and show Koichi, who looked down on me, what I can do.
examples.ja: トーフグの社長になって、コウイチを見返してやるぞ！

meaning_mnemonic:
When you <kanji>see</kanji> someone doubting you and <kanji>return</kanji> something successful instead, that is <vocabulary>to show someone what one can do</vocabulary> or more simply <vocabulary>to show someone</vocabulary>. In other words, you show someone who doubted you or treated you unfairly what you’re really capable of.

There are a couple of other meanings, too. It can mean <vocabulary>to look back over something</vocabulary>, like the answers to your kanji test you want to double check, and sometimes <vocabulary>to return someone’s stare</vocabulary>. You can see how all of these meanings relate to the kanji, right?
reading_mnemonic: The readings are from the words 見 and 返す put together.

examples.en: He decided to join the military.
examples.ja: 彼は軍に入ることを決心した。

examples.en: That country seems to be strengthening its military.
examples.ja: その国は軍を強化しているようだ。

examples.en: How's life in the military? Is training hard?
examples.ja: どう、軍の生活は？トレーニングはやっぱり大変？

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: I stood in line to buy tickets.
examples.ja: チケットを買うために列にならびました。

examples.en: A long line had formed in front of the cash register.
examples.ja: そのレジの前には長い列ができていました。

examples.en: What? Were you in the second row at Taylor Swift's concert?
examples.ja: え、テイラースイフトのコンサート、前から二列目だったんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: When things are put in a <kanji>row</kanji> they end up forming a <vocabulary>line</vocabulary>. This can be a line of people waiting in a <vocabulary>queue</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>row</vocabulary> of seats in a theater, or a <vocabulary>column</vocabulary> in Excel and other spreadsheets.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: It would be great if I had good connections, but oh well.
examples.ja: いい伝があれば良かったんだけどね。

examples.en: I'm looking for connections to interview Zuckerberg.
examples.ja: ザッカーバーグをインタビューするための伝をさがしています。

examples.en: Through whose referral did you get hired by Tofugu?
examples.ja: トーフグには誰の伝で入社したの？

meaning_mnemonic: When you get someone to <kanji>transmit</kanji> information, they're a type of <vocabulary>intermediary</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>go-between</vocabulary>, if you will.
reading_mnemonic:
When a vocab word is a single kanji with no okurigana, it takes the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember: 

When the <vocabulary>go-between</vocabulary> gets back and is about to tell you everything the other group said, it takes him <reading>two ta</reading>kes (つて) to get it all right. The other group had a lot to say and he had trouble getting it all on the first take, but he totally nailed it on the second.

Little side note: this word is actually more common in katakana, as in ツテ, or hiragana, as in つて. Still, you might see it in kanji too, and it's good if you can read it!

examples.en: I felt pathetic again today because I couldn't speak well during the presentation.
examples.ja: 今日もまたプレゼンでうまく話せなかったので、自分のことを情けないなと思いました。

examples.en: At that time, he looked very miserable.
examples.ja: 彼はその時、とても情けなさそうにしていました。

examples.en: It's sad, but I have a very trusting nature, so I often get duped.
examples.ja: 情けないんですが、すぐに人を信じる性格なので、よくだまされるんです。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen how the word 情け means pity, so adding ない to that turns it into an adjective meaning <vocabulary>pitiable</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>miserable</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: I heard that player really smashes home runs.
examples.ja: あの選手はすごいホームランを放つらしいですよ。

examples.en: Do you intend to free this bird from its cage someday?
examples.ja: この鳥をいつかカゴから放つつもりですか。

examples.en: You ought to be careful when choosing the words you fire off on social media.
examples.ja: SNSに放つ言葉は、ちゃんと選んだ方が良いですよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember 放す (to release) and 放れる (to get loose)? 放つ is another transitive verb of the <kanji>release</kanji> family, but this is a more dynamic kind of releasing, so it means <vocabulary>to fire</vocabulary> off something. 

You can remember this because you usually need つ (two) hands to fire something off properly, whether it's a slingshot or a hit in baseball.

放つ often implies setting something free with force or impact. It's used to describe things like shooting arrows, firing bullets, letting animals loose into the wild, or even strongly emitting something like light or an offensive smell. More figuratively, it can describe the act of releasing something into the world, whether that's a creative work you're unveiling or a hot take you're firing off on social media.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: Viet is good at grooming his beard.
examples.ja: ビエトは、ヒゲを整えるのが上手です。

examples.en: I practice meditation and mindfulness every morning to center my mind.
examples.ja: 私は心を整えるために、毎朝メディテーションとマインドフルネスをしています。

examples.en: I exercise and watch my diet to balance my hormones.
examples.ja: ホルモンバランスを整えるために、運動したり、食事のバランスに気をつけたりしています。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>arrange</kanji>, and the verb version also means <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to put in order</vocabulary>. This has to do with putting things in their rightful place, getting affairs in order, or even preparing equipment.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

Everything in your room has finally been <vocabulary>put in order</vocabulary>. Just as you finish, you hear a crash and turn to see your dog has jumped up onto your desk. "<reading>Toto no</reading> (ととの)!" you yell as he knocks everything over. Guess you have  <vocabulary>to arrange</vocabulary>  it all over again. Dammit Toto.

examples.en: Oh my! Lunch break is in five minutes.
examples.ja: 大変だ！あと五分で昼休みだ。

examples.en: I always eat lunch outside during lunch break.
examples.ja: 昼休みにはいつも外でランチを食べます。

examples.en: During lunch break, I'll check the news on my smartphone.
examples.ja: 昼休みに、スマホでそのニュースをチェックしてみます。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 休み means "break?" When you take a break at <kanji>noon</kanji> it's your <vocabulary>lunch break</vocabulary>! Or, if you aren't hungry, it's a <vocabulary>noon break</vocabulary> instead.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You learned them already, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: Sunny days make me want to go on a picnic.
examples.ja: 晴れの日はピクニックに行きたくなります。

examples.en: It looks like it's going to be sunny again tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日も晴れみたいだよ。

examples.en: This app says "It will be clear, then cloudy."
examples.ja: このアプリでは「晴れのちくもり」になってるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you say something is going to <kanji>clear up</kanji>, you're usually talking about the weather. That makes this <vocabulary>clear weather</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>sunny</vocabulary>.

Maybe because of those connotations, 晴れ can also be used to describe special occasions that are usually public. For example, a wedding or a big recital might be called a 晴れの場 (special occasion). Similarly, the special clothing you wear to such events is called 晴れ着 (formal attire).
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: This 24-hour supermarket was opened last year.
examples.ja: この二十四時間スーパーは、昨年オープンしました。

examples.en: I went on a trip to Guam last year.
examples.ja: 昨年は旅行でグアムに行きました。

examples.en: Finally, things have started to go well with my work since last year.
examples.ja: ようやく昨年から、だんだん仕事がうまくいき出したんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Yesterday</kanji>'s <kanji>year</kanji> was actually <vocabulary>last year</vocabulary>. Today must be New Years then!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Whoa, you're a different person when you take off the mask.
examples.ja: おっマスク外すと別人だね。

examples.en: I missed the target again.
examples.ja: またターゲットを外してしまった。

examples.en: Why did you remove Kyoko from the team?
examples.ja: どうしてキョーコをチームから外したんですか？

examples.en: Let's remove the engine.
examples.ja: エンジンを外しましょう。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.

The kanji 外 means <kanji>outside</kanji>, and the meaning of this verb is somewhat related. It means <vocabulary>to remove</vocabulary> something. Think of it like this — if you remove your watch, you are putting it "outside" of its usual spot (your wrist), right?

Like many verbs ending in す, this verb is transitive. It's used for when you intentionally take something and put it outside of where it's supposed to be — so depending on the context, it can also mean <vocabulary>to exclude</vocabulary> someone, or even <vocabulary>to miss something</vocabulary> (like a target). See how all these meanings relate to the idea of something ending up outside its intended spot?
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be a kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this one yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

If you're going <vocabulary>to remove</vocabulary> something from its usual spot, you'd better put on your <reading>haz</reading>mat (はず) suit. You know, those full body yellow onesies people wear to make sure they don't come in contact with any hazardous material. You don't know how long that thing you're removing has been there — or what kind of weird toxic stuff may have accumulated around it — so it's better to be safe than sorry.

meanings: Something Heard For The First Time

examples.en: Huh, that's the first I've heard of it.
examples.ja: ええっ、それは初耳です。

examples.en: Seriously? That's all news to me!
examples.ja: マジ？そんな話、初耳だぞ！？

examples.en: This term may be new to many of you.
examples.ja: この言葉は、初耳の人も多いかもしれませんね。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>first</kanji> time something reaches your <kanji>ear</kanji>, it's <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>. If it's never entered your ear before, it's <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to you!
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses kun'yomi instead of on'yomi readings, because 初 behaves more like a prefix here. You already know how to read 耳, but you haven't learned the kun'yomi for 初 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

Whatever it is, this <vocabulary>something heard for the first time</vocabulary>, be sure to hold onto your <reading>hats</reading> (はつ)! It's going to be something big, and I'm pretty sure it's going to be <vocabulary>news</vocabulary> to me, too.

examples.en: There were many passengers on that bus.
examples.ja: そのバスにはたくさんの乗客が乗っていました。

examples.en: Some passengers look forward to chatting with cab drivers.
examples.ja: タクシードライバーとのおしゃべりを楽しみにしている乗客もいる。

examples.en: A female passenger was waiting alone on the platform.
examples.ja: ホームには女性の乗客が一人で待っていた。

meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <kanji>ride</kanji> as a <kanji>guest</kanji> (or a <kanji>customer</kanji>), that makes you a <vocabulary>passenger</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You hopefully learned the on'yomi for 乗 with the word 乗馬, but here's a mnemonic to help you just in case:

You notice a <vocabulary>passenger</vocabulary> getting on at your stop. Who is it? The distinct smell of barn animals and manure gives it away immediately: it’s <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう), the farmhand!

examples.en: This morning, I went horseback riding.
examples.ja: 今朝、乗馬をしました。

examples.en: I want to experience horseback riding.
examples.ja: 乗馬を体験してみたい。

examples.en: Recently, I've been attending a horse riding club.
examples.ja: 最近は、乗馬クラブに通っています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>ride</kanji> a <kanji>horse</kanji>, that's <vocabulary>horseback riding</vocabulary> or, in some parts of the world, simply <vocabulary>horse riding</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 乗, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Know who loves <vocabulary>horseback riding</vocabulary>? That's right, <reading>Joe</reading> (じょう) the farmhand. It makes sense, with him being a farmhand and all.

examples.en: Do you know the origin of the name of this place?
examples.ja: この場所の名前の由来を知っていますか？

examples.en: We use ingredients from natural sources.
examples.ja: 自然由来の材料を使っています。

examples.en: This word comes from Latin.
examples.ja: この単語は、ラテン語に由来しています。

meaning_mnemonic: What's the <kanji>reason</kanji> that something <kanji>come</kanji>s into being? Its <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary>, of course. Nothing can come into the world without a <vocabulary>source</vocabulary>, because it's always <vocabulary>coming from</vocabulary> somewhere.
reading_mnemonic:
You didn't learn this reading for 由 so here's a mnemonic to help you:

The best way to get close to the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>source</vocabulary> of something is to move into a <reading>yu</reading>rt (ゆ). Yurts are easy to move around, so you can always get close to the source, wherever that may be.

examples.en: This is an onomatopoeia that expresses a sense of softness.
examples.ja: これは、やわらかいイメージを表すオノマトペですね。

examples.en: What is your favorite onomatopoeia and why do you like it?
examples.ja: 好きなオノマトペと、それが好きな理由を教えてください。

examples.en: How do you all learn Japanese onomatopoeias?
examples.ja: 日本語のオノマトペって、みんなどうやって勉強してるの？

meaning_mnemonic:
オノマトペ comes from the French word “onomatopée” which, as you can probably guess, means <vocabulary>onomatopoeia</vocabulary>.

オノマトペ has a wider meaning than its English equivalent, and it also covers <vocabulary>mimetic word</vocabulary>s, which are words that evoke ideas and actions rather than sounds.

examples.en: We're going to play poker, so can you go buy some playing cards?
examples.ja: ポーカーするからトランプ買ってきて！

examples.en: Hey, want to play cards?
examples.ja: ねえ、トランプしない？

examples.en: I'm not very good at shuffling cards.
examples.ja: トランプ切るの、苦手なんだよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
トランプ comes from the English word "trump", as in "a trump card", but it means <vocabulary>deck of cards</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>playing cards</vocabulary> in Japanese.

The Japanese meaning probably comes from card games played by English-speaking Westerners back in the day. Japanese people heard the word "trump" a lot, and assumed it meant a deck of cards.

examples.en: Why do you only suspect me?
examples.ja: なんで私ばかり疑うの？

examples.en: It was a piece of news that would make you doubt your own eyes.
examples.ja: それは自分の目を疑うようなニュースでした。

examples.en: I sometimes suspect that our dog is actually a human on the inside.
examples.ja: たまに、うちの犬の中には人間が入ってるんじゃないかなと疑うことがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>doubt</kanji>, so this is just that as a verb. So this means <vocabulary>to doubt</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to suspect</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be suspicious of</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: There's reason <vocabulary>to doubt</vocabulary> that you can teach an <reading>u</reading>ni <reading>Taga</reading>log (うたが), but once you try, it's actually not that hard. They're very good listeners after all.

examples.en: I'm afraid of climbing down the ladder.
examples.ja: ハシゴを下りるのがこわいんです。

examples.en: Dad jumped down from the fence.
examples.ja: お父さんはジャンプしてフェンスから下りた。

examples.en: My fiancé's visa finally got issued.
examples.ja: やっとフィアンセのビザが下りました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji means <kanji>below</kanji>, which is a clue to the direction this movement verb takes: this is <vocabulary>to go down</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to descend</vocabulary>. In some cases, this can also mean <vocabulary>to be issued</vocabulary>, mostly in situations where some sort of grant or allowance is issued by an authority.

You might notice that this is similar to 下る (くだる), and you can use either to describe going down a mountain. The difference is that 下る implies a gradual sloping motion, like floating down a stream, whereas you'd say 下りる if you’re jumping out of trees!
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji), you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn with the kanji. Here's a mnemonic to help you:

You're stuck on a huge mountain, and the only way <vocabulary>to go down</vocabulary> is by using your <reading>o</reading>bi (お). So you'll have <vocabulary>to descend</vocabulary> this entire mountain with nothing but your obi, acting as a rope. Good luck!

examples.en: It is a theme that questions the way society and human beings should be.
examples.ja: 社会と人間のあり方を問うテーマです。

examples.en: That player's abilities will likely be tested in next week's match.
examples.ja: その選手は来週の試合で実力が問われるだろう。

examples.en: Currently, the way schools operate is being questioned.
examples.ja: 今、学校のあり方が問われています。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>problem</kanji> and this verb means <vocabulary>to question something</vocabulary>. That's because when you want to get to the bottom of a problem, you question things.

問う has a formal, literary sound and tends to carry a sense of raising a meaningful or weighty question. You'll see it in essays, news articles, and philosophical writing when someone is considering deeper issues, like questioning values, society, or something's very existence. It can also just mean <vocabulary>to ask</vocabulary>, but will sound stuffier and more old-fashioned than the standard 聞く.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know it's probably going to use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember it:

It's okay <vocabulary>to question something</vocabulary>, but you should be careful not to step on someone else's <reading>toe</reading>s (と) by doing so. Questioning certain things can offend people, especially if it's something they have strong feelings about! So be careful about those toes.

examples.en: He has the open-mindedness to accept everything.
examples.ja: 彼は全てを受け入れる心の広さを持っています。

examples.en: People can only grow by accepting themselves.
examples.ja: 人は自分を受け入れることでしか成長できません。

examples.en: This school welcomes international students as well.
examples.ja: この学校はインターナショナルな学生も受け入れています。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember 受ける (to receive something) and 入れる (to put in)? This just combines those two. You receive something, and put it into your heart. You accept it. So this verb means <vocabulary>to accept something</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to take in</vocabulary>. 

You can use this verb for all kinds of acceptance, such as accepting an apology, accepting exchange students to your school, etc.
reading_mnemonic: You should know how to read both 受ける and 入れる, so you should be good to go!

examples.en: Could you go pick up a bottle of green tea at the convenience store for me?
examples.ja: コンビニでペットボトルの緑茶買って来てくれない？

examples.en: Lately, I've been gargling with green tea every day.
examples.ja: 最近は緑茶で毎日うがいしてるんです。

examples.en: Both have a lot of caffeine, but I prefer green tea over coffee.
examples.ja: 両方ともカフェインが強いけど、コーヒーよりも緑茶の方が好きなんです。

examples.en: Technically speaking, hojicha and matcha also fall into the category of "non-oxidized tea."
examples.ja: 厳密に言うと、ほうじ茶や抹茶も「緑茶」と言うカテゴリーに入ります。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Green</kanji> <kanji>tea</kanji> is <vocabulary>green tea</vocabulary>.

緑茶 technically refers to all kinds of green tea (i.e., non-oxidized teas). But in everyday Japanese, the word usually means green-colored tea made from leaf infusions, typically sencha.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the りょく reading for 緑 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you out:

You love your <vocabulary>green tea</vocabulary> so much that you <reading>lock</reading> (りょく) it up in a safe in your house. No one's getting to that green tea except you — it's kept under strict lock and key at all times.

examples.en: Babies lick everything.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんは何でも舐める。

examples.en: I can have alcohol as long as it's just a little taste.
examples.ja: お酒は舐めるくらいだったら飲めます。

examples.en: Don't you dare look down on me just 'cause your WaniKani level's higher!
examples.ja: 自分の方がワニカニのレベル高いからって、舐めんじゃねぇよ！

examples.en: Honestly, I underestimated the entrance exam for Tofugu University. Ugh… I should've studied more.
examples.ja: 正直なところ、トーフグ大学の入学試験は舐めてたんです。あーあ、もっと勉強すれば良かった。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>lick</kanji>, so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to lick</vocabulary>.

舐める also has a slang meaning of <vocabulary>to underestimate</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to look down on</vocabulary>. In those cases it'll often be written as ナメる or sometimes なめる. You might see it in manga or hear characters in movies say なめんなよ (don't underestimate me). Think of the slang meaning like this: you'd have to really underestimate someone to think you could just lick them without consequences, right?
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should be good to go here!
